item.description:
What is ssh-vault?

A command line tool (cli) for creating encrypted files “vaults” using ssh rsa keys for encrypt/decrypt.

A vault password is encrypted using the public ssh key of the receiver and the main data of the vault using AES256, in order to see/decrypt the vault contentes, the receiver will need to use his private key & password in case of needed to be available to edit/view the contents.

You can learn more about generaring an SSH key here: https://help.github.com/articles/generating-an-ssh-key/

Why ?

Because of the need to share sensitive data without the need to share a password.

item.title: How it works
item.description:
ssh-vault will randomly create a password and use it for encrypt the contents of the vault using a symmetric cipher AES256, the password later will be encrypted using the the ssh public RSA key of the receiver.

This helps to simplify the share of sensitive data across teams, developers, or either to store things on a public repository by just using their public ssh keys.

The option -u takes advantage of the ssh public keys stored in github:

 https://github.com/<username>.keys

Speed up more things since the vaults can be created without even asking a user for his private ssh key, basically helps to work asynchronously, the only requirement would be that the receiver needs to have an ssh-rsa public key/account on github.com

Creating a vault (encryption)

Example:

User Alice wants to send something to user Bob

Alice will type:

$ ssh-vault -u bob create vault

By doing this Alice will fetch for bob ssh public keys stored in github https://github.com/bob.keys and create a vault that only bob will be available to decrypt by using his private ssh key

In case Alice want’s to use a different key, could do:

$ ssh-vault -k /path/to/bob/id_rsa.pub create vault

Edit/View a vault (decryption)

Continuing with the previous example, if Bob want to see what Alice sent to him, just need to type:

$ ssh-vault view vault

He will be prompted for his ssh-key private password, or if he wants to use another private key, he can type:

$ ssh-vault -k ~/.ssh/id_rsa_other view vault
